segment.source: Internet Explorer 11 uses the latest standards mode, which simplifies web page compatibility for users by removing the **Compatibility View** button and reducing the number of compatibility options in the F12 developer tools for developers.
segment.target: Internet Explorer 11 uses the latest standards mode, which simplifies web page compatibility for users by removing the **Compatibility View** button and reducing the number of compatibility options in the F12 developer tools for developers.

segment.source: Missing the Compatibility View Button (Internet Explorer 11 for IT Pros)
segment.target: Missing the Compatibility View Button (Internet Explorer 11 for IT Pros)

segment.source: Missing the Compatibility View Button
segment.target: Missing the Compatibility View Button

segment.source: Applies to:
segment.target: Applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows 8.1
segment.target: Windows 8.1

segment.source: Windows 7
segment.target: Windows 7

segment.source: Windows Server 2012 R2
segment.target: Windows Server 2012 R2

segment.source: Windows Server 2008 R2 with Service Pack 1 (SP1)
segment.target: Windows Server 2008 R2 with Service Pack 1 (SP1)

segment.source: Compatibility View was introduced in Windows Internet Explorer 8 to help existing content continue to work with Windows Internet Explorer 7, while developers updated their content to support modern interoperable web standards.
segment.target: Compatibility View was introduced in Windows Internet Explorer 8 to help existing content continue to work with Windows Internet Explorer 7, while developers updated their content to support modern interoperable web standards.

segment.source: Since then, the Internet Explorer web platform, and the web itself, have changed so that most public web content looks for standards-based features instead of IE 7-compatible behavior.
segment.target: Since then, the Internet Explorer web platform, and the web itself, have changed so that most public web content looks for standards-based features instead of IE 7-compatible behavior.

segment.source: Thanks to these changes, using Internet Explorer 11 in the latest standards mode is more compatible with the web than ever before.
segment.target: Thanks to these changes, using Internet Explorer 11 in the latest standards mode is more compatible with the web than ever before.

segment.source: As a result, IE11 simplifies web page compatibility for users by removing the Compatibility View button and reducing the number of compatibility options in the F12 developer tools for developers.
segment.target: As a result, IE11 simplifies web page compatibility for users by removing the Compatibility View button and reducing the number of compatibility options in the F12 developer tools for developers.

segment.source: What happened to the Compatibility View button?
segment.target: What happened to the Compatibility View button?

segment.source: In previous versions of IE, the Compatibility View button would attempt to fix a broken standards-based website, by getting the page to appear like it did in Internet Explorer 7.
segment.target: In previous versions of IE, the Compatibility View button would attempt to fix a broken standards-based website, by getting the page to appear like it did in Internet Explorer 7.

segment.source: Today however, more standards-based websites are broken by attempting to appear like they did in Internet Explorer 7.
segment.target: Today however, more standards-based websites are broken by attempting to appear like they did in Internet Explorer 7.

segment.source: So instead of implementing and using Compatibility View, developers are updating their server configuration to add X-UA-Compatible meta tags, which forces the content to the “edge”, making the Compatibility View button disappear.
segment.target: So instead of implementing and using Compatibility View, developers are updating their server configuration to add X-UA-Compatible meta tags, which forces the content to the “edge”, making the Compatibility View button disappear.

segment.source: In support of these changes, the Compatibility View button has been completely removed for IE11.
segment.target: In support of these changes, the Compatibility View button has been completely removed for IE11.

segment.source: What if I still need Compatibility View?
segment.target: What if I still need Compatibility View?

segment.source: There might be extenuating circumstances in your company, which require you to continue to use Compatibility View.
segment.target: There might be extenuating circumstances in your company, which require you to continue to use Compatibility View.

segment.source: In this situation, this process should be viewed strictly as a workaround.
segment.target: In this situation, this process should be viewed strictly as a workaround.

segment.source: You should work with the website vendor to make sure that the affected pages are updated to match the latest web standards.
segment.target: You should work with the website vendor to make sure that the affected pages are updated to match the latest web standards.

segment.source: The functionality described here is currently deprecated and will be removed at a time in the future.
segment.target: The functionality described here is currently deprecated and will be removed at a time in the future.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: This functionality is only available in Internet Explorer for the desktop.
segment.target: This functionality is only available in Internet Explorer for the desktop.

segment.source: To change your Compatibility View settings
segment.target: To change your Compatibility View settings

segment.source: Open Internet Explorer for the desktop, click Tools, and then click Compatibility View settings.
segment.target: Open Internet Explorer for the desktop, click Tools, and then click Compatibility View settings.

segment.source: In the Compatibility View Settings box, add the problematic website URL, and then click Add.
segment.target: In the Compatibility View Settings box, add the problematic website URL, and then click Add.

segment.source: Compatibility View is turned on for this single website, for this specific computer.
segment.target: Compatibility View is turned on for this single website, for this specific computer.

segment.source: Decide if you want your intranet sites displayed using Compatibility View, decide whether to use Microsoft compatibility lists, and then click Close.
segment.target: Decide if you want your intranet sites displayed using Compatibility View, decide whether to use Microsoft compatibility lists, and then click Close.
